Description: Limestone stela of Qery-Hori: this round-topped stela in sunk relief with incised texts consists of three registers. In the upper register Isis stands on the left behind Osiris who is seated on a throne. Before him is an altar on which rests a lotus-flower. He is being worshipped by Qery-Hori or Hori who kneels with arms raised on the right. The second register depicts one woman and two men in an attitude of adoration. They are named as the chantress of Amun, Tʒ-wr(t), the attendant P(ʒ)-n-Tʒ-wrt and the attendant Bʒk-n-'Imn. In the third register one woman, the chantress of Amun, ʿn-tʒ-ḫytw and one man, the scribe ʿn-ẖr-ỉʒwt.f are shown kneeling in worship. The condition of the stela is good with only slight surface damage. There are no traces of colour.
Curator's comments: Bibliography: J. Lieblein, ‘Dictionnaire de noms hiéroglyphiques en ordre généalogique et alphabetique’ (Christiania, 1871-1891), no. 951; The British Museum, 'A guide to the Egyptian galleries (Sculpture)' (London, 1909), 184 (no. 660).
Bibliographic references: Bierbrier 1982 / Hieroglyphic texts from Egyptian stelae, etc., in the British Museum, Part 10. (pl.100)
